text: If this is true, a comparison of those letters would be fascinating.

If AG wrote that she determined that provision of service to TikTok doesn't violate the law, is there room for lawmakers to inquire about her factual support for determination? Or is that entirely a legal conclusion she can plausibly claim is shielded or privileged?

Just a tremendous honor to debate my friend @alanrozenshtein.com on the TikTok case, with @zittrain.bsky.social's expert moderation, with Justice Breyer in the front row. Even more special to have my kids there--and relieved that they (and Justice Breyer) sided with me!
Still would like to see these TikTok AG letters.  Possible that lawmakers could ask her what factual support she had to reach that conclusion.
Akamai addresses its potential liability exposure tied to TikTok in its latest 10-K. www.ir.akamai.com/sec-filings/...

9 Justices and three D.C. Circuit judges, but who's counting!

I'm just excited that Anupam and I get to keep our frenemy Vaudeville act going for a little longer.

With a sale still difficult (even more difficult now), and Republicans in Congress not looking likely to change law, seems there's a decent chance this ends up back in court, maybe after an extension of this EO underscores the defiance of the law. Doesn't seem like TikTok is out of the woods.

I don't know enough about the rest of the EO, but I think it's worth saying what this part on interpretation of law is all about. For most agencies, they are already bound to AG's position on what the law is. DOJ represents them in court. /1

In Lindke, SCOTUS set out a two-part test to address whether there's state action when a public official "uses" social media. Will test be the same to address if there's state action when a public official privately *owns and controls* a social-media platform?

www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/23p...

I'm sure that's correct about the speculativeness analysis, but it can't hurt that courts already addressed. Standing does have know-it-when-you-see-it feel. I'd think TikTok competitors would have incentive to quietly encourage a test from TikTok users.
Especially if TikTok EO gets extended past April, I'll be surprised if there is no legal challenge.
cc @alanrozenshtein.com

If TikTok users challenged EO, they wouldn't rely on a "chain of possibilities" as attenuated as in Clapper. Decent case a threatened injury is "certainly impending" when EO ignores law and keeps sending data to parent in China. DC Circuit & SCOTUS already addressed if harm was speculative.
How can she say that there has been no violation of the statute? (As opposed to saying that she won’t bring any enforcement actions pending XYZ.)
I still won’t be surprised if we see a legal challenge to the TikTok EO or any extension of it, despite likely standing complications.

If anyone has a copy of one of the AG's letters on TikTok, please share.  (There shouldn't be any legal confidentiality concerns, given that it's correspondence from a government official to a private company about the latter's legal duties and presumably doesn't reflect, e.g., trade secrets.)
It will be interesting to see exactly what Bondi’s TikTok letter said.

New: China might just let TikTok U.S. die rather than approve a sale. They have no interest in giving Trump a win unless he delivers a “grand deal” in exchange. Would embarrass the "Save TikTok" president and delight Chinese citizens, who see this as a David vs. Goliath tale wapo.st/3CH2Sy9

Trump's TikTok EO doesn't just tell the AG to exercise prosecutorial discretion (don't act). It also tells the AG to "stat[e]" in writing that there has been no violation of the statute. I wonder how the AG can make that statement.

Still can't download TikTok off the Apple or Google app stores. If that continues, we have our answer as to how much they want to risk legal liability based on Trump's word. 

@mattschett.bsky.social : Companies that reinstated TikTok already grew their “legal exposure from $0 to $850 billion"

This is right, but tricky thing is that Congress hasn't left itself time. If no unanimous consent, could take Congress days to extend/change. That's Congress's own fault. But fascinating whether it weighs on SCOTUS, which has power to adopt a brief admin stay (even if legally questionable).

Thoughts on network security, national security, AI, and my time at the FCC.

cyberscoop.com/fcc-jessica-...
Guys, C-SPAN is momentarily in a state of lawless anarchy.
One week from a SCOTUS showdown, I discussed the path ahead for TikTok on Bloomberg Radio this morning. More details in the thread linked below.
My guess: trying to insulate this decision from further review. Let's keep it simple as matter of administrative law, not tee up any questions about the future of MQD after Loper Bright.
Acknowledging ambiguity, though, would've probably forced the court to confront the major-questions doctrine.

This seems like a valid critique. 

If the last 20+ years of #netneutrality litigation shows anything, it's that there probably isn't one "plain meaning" on the classification question. That's why Chevron mattered: it let the FCC switch between alternative readings that could be called reasonable.

Carr has said he's more focused on (c)(2) than (c)(1), and he's actually spoken positively about (c)(1). Since (c)(2) rarely plays a role in actual legal cases, I think that's a pretty strong tell that this is about politics and headlines more than changing results in actual suits.

Only if the FCC insists it's interpretation of Section 230 is binding on the courts. More likely, the FCC puts out an order effectively (or at least alternatively) telling the courts what it thinks is a pretty good way to read the shield. No Loper Bright crisis there.

The holidays are behind us. Let's take a moment to consider the next few of weeks in media law.

Jan 10-TikTok Ban oral arguments
Jan 15-FSC v Paxton (Texas Age Verification)
Jan 20-Trump inauguration
Jan 21-Brendan Carr becomes chair of the FCC
Jan 22 I teach internet and advertising law in spring

With TikTok set for a critical SCOTUS showdown on January 10, what does the legal path ahead look like? Some considerations here: 

x.com/mattschett/s...

Will TikTok win at SCOTUS? It's close case, yet we doubt it. Best predictor of how SCOTUS will see case isn't Trump's brief on politics. It's how D.C. Cir. panel that's ideologically like SCOTUS already ruled on law -- unanimously, without any sign of hesitation, against TikTok.

I'm also skeptical, but SCOTUS didn't deny TikTok's request for a stay -- at least not yet. The fact that SCOTUS didn't *grant* the injunction, despite the clear urgency, may very well tell us something.

Best evidence Trump TikTok brief won't sway SCOTUS: Neomi Rao.  

Rao is often sympathetic to Trump. When she ruled in this case, she already knew what Trump's brief says: he won election; now against ban; TT loss would leave him little room.  

Didn’t matter. She handed TikTok sweeping loss.

The Supreme Court’s decision this week *not* to hear a case about ISP regulation will give states more control over telcos and cable providers, much to the chagrin of companies that fought to weaken federal regulation. Solid explainer by @haroldfeld.bsky.social www.facebook.com/share/p/1Ghd...

Here's our statement on the Supreme Court fast-tracking the TikTok case. As I say "The TikTok ban itself and the DC Circuit's approval of it should be of great concern even to those who find TikTok undesirable or scary."   www.eff.org/deeplinks/20...

Some more discussion here on how the Supreme Court is handling the TikTok appeal and what it all could mean:
youtu.be/nfsSqBEu6_Y?...

The Supreme Court could have made everyone's life easier by simply staying the operation of the law until its constitutionality were resolved. After all, the Biden Administration stopped negotiating with TikTok in 2022--letting this supposed national security risk fester for another 2 years!
Srinivasan’s concurrence offers easy path around this.

SCOTUS has declined to hear a challenge to NY State's law requiring ISPs to offer an affordable broadband speed for low-income subs. This is a big deal. www.scotusblog.com/2024/12/cour...

The fight around broadband now effectively shifts to the states, unless 6th Cir upholds Title II. /1

Most interesting part of TikTok SCOTUS filing is plea for 13-day "administrative injunction." That could offer a path for Court to deny TikTok's plea for full injunction, but also push 1/19 deadline by a couple days until Trump takes office.

Will SCOTUS stay TikTok 1/19 deadline? 

Some chance, but SCOTUS:

-must have 5 votes to issue stay
-denies *many* more stay pleas than it grants
-won't lightly halt a national-security deadline
-probably agrees w DC Cir ruling by Ginsburg, Rao, Srinivasan

This @jadler1969.bsky.social piece is excellent.  (Or summary of a piece.  The actual essay wasn't loading for me).  

There is no magic wand to "pause" or "suspend" the regulatory state.  Deregulation takes as much time and bureaucratic talent as regulation.

I wrote about the TikTok case and what, exactly, the government thinks we should be so afraid of.

Expect the D.C. Circuit to deny TikTok's request for an injunction blocking the Jan. 19 deadline, possibly today but more likely Friday or Monday.

US tells D.C. Circuit that TikTok users may "continue to use the platform for at least some time" after Jan. 19, yet sale-or-ban law will "eventually . . . render the application unworkable." The parties haven't explored "how quickly the application will cease to function."

Though it's a closer question whether TikTok can get pause of 1/19 deadline, TikTok's chances of winning its suit against the sale-or-ban law aren't good.

Thanks to @viacristiano.bsky.social and @drewharwell.com 
for picking up on my analysis @washingtonpost.com

Will TikTok win at the US Supreme Court in challenge to US sale-or-ban law? The company is a significant underdog, we believe. Here was my appearance on Bloomberg Friday, December 6, just after the D.C. Circuit decision came out. 

www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/...
The DC Circuit not only upholds the ban, but claims that the ban FURTHERS First Amendment values. A really remarkable argument that I worry SCOTUS will like.

Enjoyed joining @bloomberg.com live after the D.C. Circuit ruled on the TikTok ban today. We had warned that the court was likely to rule this AM, and that TikTok would likely lose. The sweeping loss for the company came in a little after 10am.

New: The TikTok sale-or-ban law is constitutional, a high-level appeals court says. The app, with 170 million U.S. users, could be banned nationwide next month. Next stop: the Supreme Court and a showdown with Trump, who's vowed to "save TikTok" however he can www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2...

Analyst @mattschett.bsky.social says it's "a sweeping loss for TikTok that will be difficult to undo." Estimates a 20% chance in the Supreme Court. 

@davidgreene.bsky.social of @eff.org: "Restricting the free flow of information, even from foreign adversaries, is fundamentally undemocratic"
Watch for D.C. Circuit ruling on US TikTok ban on Friday morning. The parties asked the court to rule by that date, and the court is likely to try to honor that request.

Gave an update to @bloomberg.com on the latest on TikTok litigation this morning. If the D.C. Circuit sticks to its routine of Tuesday/Friday decisions, we may see the ruling on Friday AM.

Looks like no TikTok decision today from D.C. Circuit. High probability it hits Friday morning (though it's no certainty: courts do what they want, when they want to do it!)

One potential big difference at the FCC between Trump's first and second terms: 

In first, the FCC often agreed w Trump on policy yet also remained independent (eg Sinclair, 230 rules). 

In second, that's in serious doubt. Good chance this FCC does what the president demands.

The US Supreme Court relisted the nondelegation case challenging the FCC's universal service program for a Nov. 22 conference. There's a solid chance SCOTUS will take the case after that conference. www.supremecourt.gov/search.aspx?...
Trump has said he plans to keep TikTok available to Americans--but his new FCC chair, Brendan Carr, has been hoping for a "total ban" on TikTok since at least 2022: www.npr.org/2022/12/23/1...

And with that buildup ... the court doesn't act on any of the big cases except to turn away a secondary appeal in one of the pending trans athlete cases. Next scheduled orders list is a week from today.

With Trump signaling he'll elevate Brendan Carr to FCC chair, will Carr still defend a TikTok ban? He's been its biggest supporter.
